title: About
text:
Brian Vancil is a data scientist at the University of Kansas.





data science
data visualization
data cleaning and structuring
pay equity studies. These are mostly linear regressions for legal interpretability.
hierarchical time-series forecasting
Git for version control
SAS (base SAS 9.4) for data cleaning and analysis
Tableau (Desktop and Server)
Oracle (database queries, Oracle Analytics Cloud (OAC), Oracle Business Intelligence Enterprise Edition (OBIEE), Data Visualization (DV))
Quarto for reports and presentations. Yes, you can use SAS with Quarto.
Snakemake for managing data pipelines
Nuance Dragon Naturally Speaking Professional augmented with Natlink, Dragonfly, and Caster for dictating code and building grammars
AutoHotkey for combining with Caster to automate Windows interactions
Python mostly for scripting these days
Sass: Syntactically Awesome Style Sheets and Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) for styling Quarto, SAS, and OAC
TeX/LaTeX/XeLaTeX/MathJax for typesetting mathematics
Graphviz and Mermaid | Diagramming and charting tool for diagrams





Stan for Bayesian hierarchical modeling
R (package development, data pipelines, Shiny dashboards)
Python (data analysis, scripting, query generation)
dbt to manage an analytic reporting schema and data pipelines
Asymptote for creating diagrams for student worksheets

You can see a variety of my teaching blog posts at Earth and Not-Earth | Teaching Earth & Space Science through Modeling and Fock Physics | Building up physics learning one state at a time.




Programming

Python
R Statistical Programming Language
Haskell Language
Julia Programming Language (learning)
Rust Programming Language (learning)

Reading (mostly sci-fi and fantasy)
Growing native plants from seeds, including a few bonsai
Replacing our turf grass lawn with native habitat
Hiking
Steeping and drinking tea and tisanes





Washburn University | Topeka, Kansas Teacher licensure in 6-12 mathematics with secondary licenses in 6-8 science, Earth science, chemistry, and physics | 2009-2011
Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey | New Brunswick/Piscataway, NJ MA in Physics and Astronomy | 2003 - 2007
Leland Stanford Junior University | Stanford, CA BS in Physics and BS in Mathematics | 1998 - 2002

title: Licenses for this repository
text:
All the files inside the posts and directory and all files with qmd or md or html extensions are licensed under CC BY-SA 4.0. The attribution requirement is only met when:

The canonical link is directed towards the original article, e.g. <link rel="canonical" href="https://bvancil.github.io/blog/about.html" />
The following message is displayed above and below the article: This article has been originally published on <a href="https://bvancil.github.io/blog/">Brian Vancil's blog</a>.




All the files inside source/img/photos directory are copyrighted to Brian Vancil. All rights reserved.



I don’t know who has the copyrights for screenshots inside source/img/screenshots, so I don’t state any license for these files.



All the files inside source/img/logos directory are copyrighted to their respective companies.



Files not mentioned in previous paragraphs are licensed under the MIT License.

title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

Since this post doesn’t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.
